s.text: I blurbed The Kiss . The book scared me, not because it concerns incest or happens to be true but because of the malign figure of the father, who reminded me of the character played by Robert Mitchum in The Night of the Hunter . I also appreciated the drugged cadence of the prose, with a chasm between every two sentences, and the frozen stare of the insistent present tense.
But the very notion of incest-- the last taboo --unhinges readers, and they transfer blame onto Harrison, in effect accusing her of having engineered her own defilement.
But the very notion of incest-- the last taboo --unhinges readers, and they transfer blame onto Harrison, in effect accusing her of having engineered her own defilement.
But the very notion of incest-- the last taboo --unhinges readers, and they transfer blame onto Harrison, in effect accusing her of having engineered her own defilement.
And anyway, who cares whether your kitchen-sink epic features short, fat Mom and Dad or tall, thin contract players?
Also underfoot is the venerable "cousin Don" theory of literature--you know: "You're a writer?
Also underfoot is the venerable "cousin Don" theory of literature--you know: "You're a writer?
Critics are as frantic about saving their novel these days as they were about killing it 40 years ago.

In Harrison's case, it became the centerpiece of a multiple-count indictment handed down by Michael Shnayerson in the February Vanity Fair , the fallout of which was that The New Yorker killed a scheduled excerpt.
Obviously I was well aware of the holy-shit factor, sufficiently high that it could swamp all discussion and become the sole focus of criticism.
They're over quickly and forgotten by all--except, perhaps, their often hapless targets.
